entry.et: Middle English, from Middle French liquide, from Latin liquidus, from liquēre to be fluid; akin to Latin lixa water, lye, and perhaps to Old Irish fliuch damp

def.dt: :having the properties of a liquid :being neither solid nor gaseous
:being musical and free of harshness in sound
:articulated without friction and capable of being prolonged like a vowel a liquid consonant
:consisting of or capable of ready conversion into cash liquid assets
:capable of covering current liabilities quickly with current assets
:a fluid (as water) that has no independent shape but has a definite volume and does not expand indefinitely and that is only slightly compressible

:an organic liquid whose physical properties resemble those of a crystal in the formation of loosely ordered molecular arrays similar to a regular crystalline lattice and the anisotropic refraction of light
:a unit or series of units for measuring liquid capacity see metric system table weight table
:gas chromatography in which the stationary phase is a liquid
